Plant Variety Rights To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth government: I. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security. 2. Recognize that plant breeding is a highly cooperative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection, storage, search has been publicly funded. 3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognize that any system giving 'property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust. 4. Recognize that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely: (i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm, (ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes, (iii) farmer unrest at seed prices, (iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals, (v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack. 5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the draft Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray. by Mr Milton. Petition received. Clauses 1 and 2-by leave-taken together.  sition has already indicated that it will oppose this legislation; in addition, a number of the clauses are of such significance that we shall also be opposing them and dividing the Committee on them. I have a question for the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) in relation to the short title of the Bill. It is the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage (Interim Protection) Bill. A problem with the legislation that the Opposition has already raised is the fact that it is so wide. Its application to all land in Australia makes it, as the Leader of the House (Mr Young) said today, an Aboriginal land rights Act. Our concern is that not only are the implications of the Bill very wide, but also is the Minister's discretion extraordinarily wide. The basis of that concern is that it is legislation not to protect sacred sites but to protect Aboriginal areas. I shall go on to the definitions when we come to the definitions clause. But, undoubtedly, the legislation is very wide. The title of the Bill refers to heritage. I ask the Minister why the Government used that title. It seems to me that it is entirely misleading. The World Heritage Properties Conservation Act, which was passed by the Parliament last year, refers to the definition in the Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage. That makes it quite clear what is being protected. Article 1 of the Convention specifies what are considered to be part of the cultural heritage, for example, monuments. It details what are considered to be monuments, for example, architectural works, works of monumental sculpture and painting, elements or structures of an archaeological nature, inscriptions, cave dwellings and combinations of features which are of outstanding universal value from the point of view of history, art or science. The other classifications or categories which are covered in cultural heritage are groups of buildings and sites. Under Article 2 of the Convention the definition of 'natural heritage' includes natural features consisting of physical and biological formations or groups of such formations which are of outstanding universal value from the aesthetic or scientific point of view. The definition of 'heritage' is well known and quite precise. Our concern is that this legislation is not precise. The Minister sought during the debate last night to limit the operation of this Bill. He said that he will not use the Bill as widely as it might be interpreted but when we have asked him to restrict the legislation to the actual areas in which he wishes it to operate he has not been willing to do so. I suggest to the Minister that the title is misleading. People referring to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage (Interim Protection) Bill might think that it is aimed at protecting sacred sites or areas of significance to the Aboriginal people which they may think are sacred sites and, perhaps, limited areas around them. As the Minister has made clear, that is not the intention of the legislation. It is to protect Aboriginal areas and it is extraordinarily wide. That is fundamental to our concern. Therefore, it is our view that the title of the Bill is misleading. I ask the Minister why he chose that title and why he is not willing to limit this legislation to the purposes which he has stated rather than the broad purposes about which we have expressed concern.

text: It is my view that the definition of 'Aboriginal' is far too loose. Clause 3 (1) defines 'Aboriginal' as: . . . a member of the Aboriginal race of Australia, and includes a descendant of the indigenous inhabitants of the Torres Strait Islands . . . That definition of Aboriginal people in Australia is far too loose and does not do anything to identify the problems of the Aboriginal people as they face those problems. As 1 pointed out last night in my speech in the second reading debate, there are great differences in the problems faced by the Aboriginal people because they are not all full-blood Aboriginals. Some, of course, are full-blood Aboriginals but others are part-blood Aboriginals; some live in urban centres and some in their tribal land areas. However, to simply accept a definition of an Aboriginal as being one who identifies himself as being an Aboriginal does not give this Parliament or any of the State parliaments the opportunity to be able to bring in programs that can be specifically designed for the problems faced by those different categories of Aboriginals. 1 think it is quite wrong and we are deceiving ourselves and the Aboriginal people if we say that the problems being faced by part-blood Aboriginals are the same as those being faced by fullblood tribal Aboriginals. 1 believe that while it may well be to the advantage of those people, who for reasons of course that were beyond their control, not to be full-blood Aboriginals or not to be full-blood Europeans it is certainly no criticism of those people. Their skin colour is different and therefore they identify differently from full blooded Aboriginals and Europeans. They have a different set of problems and if we are to face those problems we have to face the fact that they are different. Just as those people have difficulty of sigin integrating into a European community, and we have to acknowledge that, we also have to acknowledge that they have the same difficulty in being accepted and integrated into full-blood tribal Aboriginal people. To simply accept this sort of loose definition does not give this Parliament, or an)\future parliament, the opportunity of framing programs that can be designed to help those people in the problems that they face. 1 seriously say to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding), his Department and any future Ministers who may occupy that portfolio that instead of pushing this matter under the carpet, and therefore denying the opportunity of bringing in programs to help Aboriginal people regardless of their situation or the degree of Aboriginal blood that they may have in their veins, we should bite that bullet, face up to that situation and be far more definitive in our definition of who is an Aboriginal so that we can bring in programs that will give them the help that they deserve.

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Title: INCOME AND ASSETS TEST
text: For the information of honourable members, I present the report of the Panel of Review of the Proposed Income and Assets Test, May 1984. I seek leave to make a statement. Leave granted.

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Title: INCOME AND ASSETS TEST
text: I would like to inform the House of the Government's policy on the asset testing of pensions in the light of its consideration of the report of the Panel of Review of the Proposed Income and Assets Test. The Government is firmly committed to the principle that pensions be directed to those reliant upon such expenditure an;Lnot dissipated upon those who, by any reasonable standard, do not require such assistance. In current circumstances, where many Australians with little or no income or assets are in need of additional assistance, and where there are severe limits on the resources available to meet those needs, there is no escaping the necessity to apply means tests to social security type pensions. A means test has always been applied to pensions in Australia. In a world of unlimited res:mrces, a Government might prefer to avoid such tests. But we do not live in such a world, and do not expect and to to do for the foreseeable future. These realities were faced squarely by Australians in this chamber a little over one year ago, at the National Economic Summit Conference. Then, in the depths of Australia's greatest economic crisis for half a century, Australians recognised that the restoration of the greatness of our country would require each of us to moderate our pursuit of narrow individual self-interest. The Summit communique acknowledged the overwhelming desire of the nation to ensure that those in genuine need were adequately supported, whether they were the rich, the aged, the disabled, the unemployed or the impoverished. The spirit of the Summit has served Australia well over the past year, in ways that are reflected more widely in greater social cohesion and more effective economic performance. We must continue in that spirit, because a great deal remains to be done. Within this spirit, there must be effective means testing of welfare payments to ensure that we are able to provide effectively for Australians in genuine need. The challenge for the Government is to restructure such tests to ensure that they produce genuinely equitable results. Until eight years ago the Australian means test was based on both incomes and assets. Since 1976, there has been widespread concern about wealthy people receiving a pension because their wealth has been in assets which have been structured to avoid earning current income. This basic inequity has worried many Australians, including many on both sides of this Parliament and will do so for as long as our means test fails to bring assets as well as income to account. Inevitably, the absence of an assets test has invited the emergence of income test avoidance schemes. Standard avoidance packages are now readily available and widely used and are proliferating. So in last year's Budget we moved to reintroduce assessment of assets as well as income in the means test, along the lines of the arrangements which had been in force prior to 1976. We made it clear then that there would be widespread consultation with the community before the final form of the test was settled. These consultations led to a number of modifications being incorporated into the draft Bill which was introduced into the Parliament late last year. That draft legislation sought to reduce important inequities in the means test, to address the increasingly important problem of test avoidance, and to strengthen our capacity to provide adequately for Australians in need through the long period ahead when the ratio of aged to working Australians was going to be rising. But it became clear early this year that there was continuing uncertainty about whether the Government had found the fairest and most equitable way toimplement an assets test. We became concerned that many ordinary pensioners had been caused unnecessary worry by those who, for short-sighted political purposes, encouraged groundless fears about our intentions. But, as a Government which acknowledged that it is not the repository of all wisdom, we also recognised that there was justifiable concern that we might not have found the best way to test assets. Accordingly, on 23 February, the Government reaffirmed its commitment to the assets test, and moved to establish a broadly-based panel of relevant community representatives to advise on how this principle could best be reflected in legislation. We were fortunate cure the services of high calibre representatives of. that. a wide range of interested community groups. The panel has worked hard and sulted widely since early March. It has produced a report of high quality in a short space of time. The report contributes significantly standing of the issues. On behalf of the Government, I would like to thank Professor Gruen and ity the members of the Panel for their thorough, analytical work. The weight of the report in increased by the panel having adopted a unanimous approach on most matters. The report makes a large number of specific recommendations, all of which have been carefully considered by the Government. The report as a whole has influenced the Government to change its approach to the assets test. But, as the Government, we must be the final arbiter of the national interest, and on one central matter we have chosen a different course from that preferred by the panel. The panel responsibly acknowledges the fiscal realities within which any Australian government must operate. It recognises that it is simply not feasible in the foreseeable future to move towards a system of universal pensions, while maintaining and increasing the provision for Australians in need. Thus, recognising that a needs-based system must be retained at least for some time, the panel concludes that a test must take account of both income and assets if it is to be both a fair measure of need and equitable to all. That is a strong conclusion from a group that includes a range of pensioner and service organisations. It is a conclusion that is in line with responsible economic opinion in Australia. It is a view which we are accustomed to hear from businessmen, bureaucrats, economists and the financial press. For example, a recent statement from the Business Council of Australia had this to say: Over recent years business leaders have urged that welfare payments be means tested and we have said that the Government deserves support for attempting to tackle this politically difficult problem now . . .

Finally, I ask honourable members opposite to note in particular the following comment of the Business Council of Australia: It would be disappointing if any sector of the community, through vested interest or for short-term political advantage, were to make the task of reform more difficult. But the panel's statement on means testing has special significance as a statement from a group that, collectively, can claim close association with and understanding of the particular groups which would be affected by an assets test. This alone makes the report an important development in Australian discussion of social security matters. I hope that the members of this Parliament can at least find common ground here on the need for assets as well as income to be considered in any test of need. My Government is firmly of this view. I think that honest members of the Opposition acknowledge that they share this view. I remind the House again in that context that in October 1981, the then Minister for Social Security, Senator Chaney, was reported as admitting that there was a belief in the Liberal Party that an assets-based test was the only way to stop the artificial lowering of incomes in order to get the pension. The same Liberal Minister for Social Security said in May of that year: 'I think we cannot escape the fact that there are some genuinely needy pensioners in 'this country who do not receive enough help, while some other people by the advantageous arrangement of their assets, are able to draw on the system to a greater extent than their real degree of need would seem to justify'. The Government and the panel can agree wholeheartedly with Senator Chaney's statement. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) also seems to favour an assets test, although he expressed doubts about the particular shape of the income and assets test proposed in the last Budget. On 27 November 1983, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition said: I'm personally in favour ment of welfare . . . 1 think the method of the asset test now proposed and originally in operation is not the best way of doing it, because, for example, why is it that you can have an unlimited amount of antiques or jewellery but you can only have a very small amount in the bank or in a building society deposit. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition is clearly suggesting that he would support reintroduction of an assets test if anomalies of the type he outlined were removed. It is time for us all to recognise that the real issue is not whether we should have an assets test but what is the fairest and best form of assets test. On this, the Government recognises quite straightforwardly that honest and reasonable people can hold different views. Following its consideration of the Panel's report, the Government has adopted a policy which differs from that which is incorporated in the draft legislation that is currently before the House. The Panel concludes that, while the then proposed income and assets test generally directs assistance to those most in need, it creates several anomalies and disadvantages in doing so. The extensive exemptions create inequities. The test favours those who are able to invest their assets at a rate greater than 10 per cent. In these and other ways the Panel is of the view that it is inferior to two other possible forms of assets test which it describes as the 'tall poppies test' and the 'modified tall poppies test'. The Government acknowledges the force of the Panel's argument, and has decided to put aside the previously proposed test. While the Panel is clearly of the view that the previously proposed legislation is the least satisfactory of the three possibilities that it considered, it is less clear-cut in its judgment between the other two. The Panel's 'tall poppies test' provides for the gradual phasing out of the pension when the total value of assets, without any exemption, exceeds a high figure for a single pensioner and a separate, higher sum for a couple. The Panel's' 'modified tall poppies test' exempts the house of residence up to a value of $150,000 and provides for the gradual phasing out of the pension when the total value of other assets exceeds thresholds that are lower than those applied in the 'tall poppies test'. In the final conclusions and recommendations the report prefers the 'tall poppies test'. However, in comparing the options in detail, it sees relative strengths and weaknesses in each of the two options. The report states that there would be no general community view on whether the 'tall poppies test' was fairer than the 'modified tall poppies of a needs approach to the paytest'. It is clear from the argument in the body of the report that the 'tall poppies test', without any exemption, is preferred mainly because the exemption of the home is inequitable between people who reside in their own homes and other pensioners. If it were possible to correct the imbalance between these two groups in other ways the report's strongest arguments for avoiding the exemption of the home would be met. The Panel notes two reasons why some Australians would think it fairer to exempt the house: The strong Australian belief that there is a special attachment to home ownership and the difference between levels of other assets that could be held by people occupying similar housing in different locations and with different values if the home were not exempt. Moreover, the Panel notes several advantages of the 'modified tall poppies test' over its preferred option. These include reduced opportunities for artificial avoidance schemes to operate-given that many other assets are easier to manipUlate for these purposes than a residence-and somewhat easier administration. Like the Panel, the Government believes that fairness is of fundamental importance to the operation of a means test and that fairness, like beauty, is, to some extent, in the eye of the beholder. The Government believes that in Australia it is fairer to allow exemption of the home, as long as the inequity that this introduces in relation to people who do not own their own homes is addressed in other ways. We will implement the Panel's modified tall poppies test, with some variations. The key features of the new assets test are as follows: The principal residence is completely excluded from the test. We believe that needless anxiety would be created amongst pensioners who would never actually be affected by the test if the exemption were allowed only up to a specified limit. For pensioners on farms, the exemption relates to the home and curtilage. Pensioner couples resident in their own homes receive the full pension unless the market value of their other assets exceeds $100,000. If this threshold is exceeded the pension is reduced by $20 per week for each $10,000 of other assets above $100,000. Eligibility for the pension is not eliminated, at the current rate of pension, until other assets exceed about $175,000. A homeowning pensioner couple with other assets of about $137,000 receives a half-pension. Single pensioners who are resident in their own homes receive the full pension unless the market value of their other assets exceeds $70,000. If this threshold is exceeded the pension is similarly reduced. Eligibility for the pension is not eliminated until other assets exceed about $115,000. A home-owning single pensioner with other assets of about $92,000 receives a half-pension. The exemption levels are $50,000 higher for all pensioners who are not resident in their own homes, such as renters, people living with relatives and people living permanently in nursing homes. Thus a single pensioner who is not resident in his or her own home can hold $165,000 in other assets before losing all entitlement to the pension, while a pensioner couple in the same circumstances can hold $225,000. The assets test applies only if the resulting pension entitlement is lower than that produ.ced by the current income text alone. The two tests apply separately so that one or the other, but not both, operate. In practice, this means that the assets test affects only those with substantial assets and little income. These are a small proportion of pensioners with large assets. The system of administration depends heavily on self-declaration, especially in relation to normal personal effects. This makes the administration less costly and less intrusive than would otherwise be the case. To minimise intrusion into the personal affairs of pensioners, a net market value of $10,000 is set on normal household contents and personal effects, with a provision for people to claim a lower amount if they consider $10,000 to be in excess of the actual value of the relevant assets. There is also a requirement that people declare the value of household contents and personal effects if that value exceeds $10,000. The thresholds of $70,000 for single pensioners and $100,000 for couples, as well as the addition of $50,000 for people who do not own their own homes, are to be indexed yearly in accordance with movements in the consumer price index. Several other details of the arrangements follow directly the Panel's recommendations. From today any gifts or other forms of divestment without adequate financial consideration in excess of $2,000 a year for a single pensioner and $4,000 a year for a pensioner couple are to be considered as assets of the pensioner for purposes of the test. Special aids for disabled people are exempted from the assets test. Legislation will be drafted for introduction on Budget night with a view to its early passage. The assets test applies to all social security and repatriation service pensions that are currently subject to the incomes test. Thus it does not apply to blind pensions, to unemployment and sickness benefits, or to war widow pensions and repatriation disability pensions. There are special provisions to ease problems that arise in conditions of hardship. These will be along the lines of provisions in the previous Bill, although one additional facility is available to alleviate hardship should the pensioner wish to use it. People may have assets large enough to diminish eligibility for the pension, but hold these in a form which is difficult to convert into cash to cover the ordinary expenses of living. Alternatively, they may prefer not to sell particular assets for these purposes. In these circumstances, people who hold three-quarters of their assets in these liquid forms have the right, on their own choosing, to be paid an income equivalent to the pension as a loan to be recovered from their estate. Interest would accumulate on the loans at a market related rate. I stress that no one is obliged to use this facility. It is available to eligible Australians affected by the assets test who choose to use it. The lien on the estate is similar to facilities made available by many local authorities in Australia, which allow pensioners to postpone payments of rates. Since last August's Budget Speech, we have seen a continuing attempt by honourable members opposite, with the Leader of the Oppo exaggerate and to misrepresent matters related to the assets test, for their own short-sighted political purposes. The Opposition has deliberately played on the anxieties of elderly Australians. Mr Donald Cameron-That is a lie and you know it. Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mrs Child)Order! The honourable gentleman will withdraw. Mr Donald Cameron-He is dishonest. I withdraw, Madam Deputy Speaker. Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER-Thank you.

MrHA WKE-It removes the inequity that has existed in the pension system since 1976, that assets-rich people are able to maintain pension eligibility when less wealthy people who, on any reasonable criteria, are in greater need, lose entitlement under the income test. The savings in later years will be greater to the extent that Australians in future take more assets to retirement, through the growth of entitlement to superannuation lump sums, and through the coming to retirement of a generation whose lifetime accumulation of assets, unlike that of their parents, has not been affected by depression and the Second World War. The savings in later years will be greater to the extent that artificial schemes to avoid the income test would have proliferated in the absence of an assets test. Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Title: INCOME AND ASSETS TEST
text: The report argues that any savings from the assets test should be applied to improve conditions of pensioners in greatest need. The report emphasises the special plight of pensioners who do not own their own homes. The Government is committed in the coming Budget to some general increase in the pension rate above the amounts that follow from the automatic adjustments for increases in the consumer price index. The Government will make additional assistance available to pensioner renters through an increase in the rate of supplementary assistance. Final decisions on these matters will be taken in the Budget context. Our fiscal circumstances will not allow us to do all that we would like to improve the lot of Australians in need, but we will do what we can within the limits of fiscal responsibility. Today's announcement should also be seenÂ· in the context of an ongoing discussion of wider questions of retirement incomes. The reintroduction of an assets test is one of several measures that we have taken to increase our capacity to assist Australians in need within severe fiscal constraints. We are continuing to examine the implications of various alternative forms of national superannuation schemes, as well as of alternative approaches to the extension of occupational superannuation. It would be possible, and In current circumstances even attractive from a narrow political point of view, to follow the course that the Leader of the Opposition sometimes seems to be suggesting, and to put off all hard decisions until there is widespread community support for some utopian final solution to Australia's retirement incomes problems. But a government that cares about the long term future of Australia must act with greater courage. There is no avoiding the reality that the long term evolution of the Australian retirement incomes system must, as a matter of social, demographic and economic necessity, be based on allocation of public assistance on the basis of need. The assets test, together with our initiatives on the taxation of lump sum superannuation, and on income testing the over-70 pension, represent a necessary focus on needs. I would hope that those opposite, particularly the Leader of the Opposition, would remember what he and they once understood, because it is a fact that the Leader of the Opposition did once understand these things. On 9 September 1981, then, as a Government back bencher here, the now Leader of the Opposition told this House: The Government needs to reassess its approach to spending, concentrating on the areas of genuine need, cutting out expenditure to those who do not need assistance.

Opposition)(11.46) - Of all the times that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has come into this Parliament allegedly taking the high road and invoking the language of consensus, this statement that we have had inflicted upon us today has to be the most hypocritical to date. Title: INCOME AND ASSETS TEST
text: I move: That the Medical Services (Fees) Ordinance 1984 (No. 7 of 1984), made under the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910, be disallowed. This motion relates to an action by this Government which is as futile and as extraordinary in its way, although only in a minor way in the Australian Capital Territory, as the assets test which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) announced for the elderly this morning. Just as the announced assets test is to take on 1,500 Public Service inspectors, intrude into every pensioner's household in the whole of Australia and cost $30m in its first year and bring in only a miserable $45m in subsequent years, we have from the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) an ordinance to control fees of doctors in the Australian Capital Territory; fees which are already within the bounds set by this Government and this Minister. The ordinance and statutory rules that were introduced by the Government seek to fix medical fees that may be charged to private patients in public hospitals perpein the Australian Capital Territory for certain medical diagnostic services. These services are prescribed under section 17 (1)(a) of the Health Insurance Act. SoÂ· far the prescribed services which are identified in the health insurance regulations amendment are restricted to diagnostic pathology services and radiology although the Minister has made it clear that he sees these being extended to other services at a later date. The background to this matter is the dispute with the doctors earlier this year. The Minister has said over a period of months, certainly since the introduction of the Medicare Levy Bill last year, that the costs of the services of diagnostic specialists, mainly pathologists and radiologists but a few other services, were excessive; that these people were charging in excess of schedule fees, that they were not paying satisfactory dues to the public hospital facilities which they used for their practices and that, therefore, the Government had to come in and control their contracts with the public hospitals and take urgent steps to duce these costs. That was the background to this measure. In the Medicare Levy Bill of September year the Minister introduced the notorious section 17 of the Health Insurance Act and under this sought to take total control, without any right appeal, over the contracts between private doctory. tors and public hospitals where the doctors treating their own patients in those hospitals. The rational for taking this extraordinary step, which was a way around the amendment to section 51 the Constitution which prohibits civil conscription of doctors, was based on the claim that ologists and radiologists were charging excessive fees beyond the schedule fee. Section 17 of Health Insurance Act, as the Opposition warned the Minister in September last year during the Medicare debate, would be resented by indepenthey dent private medical specialists, not just the pathwhich ologists and radiologists but all specialists-the orthopaedic surgeons, the general surgeons, the anaesthetists, the whole lot of them-because they knew, or at least they subthe sequently found out, that the Minister had section 17 of the Health Insurance Act the powers to control all doctors contracts, not just those diagnostic specialists. Indeed they also found that the Minister had said in a speech to the tors Reform Society last year that he had the tention of extending these controls to all specialities in due course. The whole of Medicare is of the ilk that nobody shall do better than anyone else; nobody shall be allowed to spend private money to get additional treatment. The people who choose to insure privately or to ask for a private doctor, who do not spend their money at the TAB or pub and who do not go on overseas holidays, who are thrifty and who wish, by their own free choice, to spend more of their disposable income on health, because they wish to have a private professional relationship with their doctor, are the sorts of people that this Government hates. This Government hates anybody who is trying to do better than anybody else, who is ing to achieve more than anybody else, who is saving more, who is thrifty and who perhaps enjoys the fruits of his work. That is the sort of person this Government hates and cannot abide. Today in this House we had two examples of that. One of these was of monumental proportions with the Prime Minister himself coming into the House and describing the miserable philosophy of this Government. Now in the Australian Capital Territory when the doctors are already minding their own business, charging the schedule fees, paying facility charges to the public hospitals whose equipment they use, operating professionally, honourably, satisfactorily and within the cost constraints declared by the Minister, the Minister comes into this House with a price control ordinance and regulation which will fix the fees the doctors are already charging. Speaker: Mr HUMPHREYS
Title: TRAFFICKING
text: Has the attention of the Special Minister of State been drawn to a recent article which suggests that the Sunshine Coast of Queensland is the centre of a drug running operation? Is the Minister in a position to comment on that article? Can he also comment on statements suggesting that the Federal Government is neglecting the fight against drug trafficking in Australia?

Speaker: Mr YOUNG
Title: TRAFFICKING
text: I will read some lines from a document. If members of the Opposition want me to table it, I will be quite happy to do so. My attention has been drawn not only to the Age article involved in the question asked by the honourable member for Boothby yesterday but also to other articles that have appeared in the Press in various parts of Australia. I have sought and received information on these matters from the Australian Federal Police. Indeed, as is the practice of the relationship between the AFP and the Minister, I have been kept informed of police operations which could be connected with the broad ambit of the matters canvassed by the Melbourne Age and other newspapers. It is not my intention, nor has it been the tion of any previous Minister for the AFP, to lay out before the House details of any current police investigations which may have some connection with the matters alluded to. It has never been the practice of governments to publicise details of sensitive and ongoing operations, something that I am sure the honourable member for Bass could confirm. However, I make the observation that it appears that the Melbourne Age has run a thread through snippets taken from a range of current police operations and tied that thread to various aspects of work which has been done by various royal commissions and other criminal intelligence agencies. While that represents a very plausible story, some of the conclusions being made in the Press seem to be running well ahead of current police intelligence on these matters. Beyond that, I do not intend to comment on the specifics of the articles. I am sure that honourable members would recognise it as being irresponsible if I did. I now turn to the suggestion that perhaps this Government is not in some way fair dinkum about combating drug trafficking and organised crime in this country. Let me refute that by saying several things. The previous Government addressed the question by the establishment of the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence. We have continued the support for that organisation and have consolidated it by the unanimous support given to it by all the State governments. We are committed to the establishment of a National Crime Authority which will be set up, take over from and continue the work of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking as soon as the legislation has passed both Houses. When looking at the Costigan Royal Commission, it is interesting to note that in the first year of our office we increased its staff from 69 to 120. We increased the expenditure for the Costigan Royal Commission from $2.96m to $6.38m in one year so that the resources required by Commissioner Costigan in his fight and investigation into these matters was as he requested. That, of course, was a direct response to many of the things that had been exposed in his earlier reports. In the latest announcement by the Government on the administrative changes to coastal surveillance, it will again be noted that coastal surveillance has now been put under the charter of the Australian Federal Police. The three units that will be set up on the ground in North Queensland, north western Australia, after consultations with intenboth State governments, and Darwin are primarily aimed at drug trafficking in those areas. I also take the opportunity of outlining some of the more significant successes of the Australian Federal Police in the past few months working with the assistance of the Australian Customs Service and, on many occasions, with other intelligence agencies and the State police forces. In June of last year, approximately 35 kilos of heroin was seized; in August, 27 kilos of heroin and in December, 70 kilos of cannabis resin. Over the New Year period, 23 kilos of heroin were seized and in January, 264 kilos of cannabis resin. In February-March, a seizure was made of 2.2 tonnes of cannabis resin. In March of this year, two seizures were made of 89 kilos of hashish oil and 260 kilos of cannabis resin. In April, 28 kilos of heroin were seized and, just last month, two tonnes of cannabis resin were picked up. It must be noted, of course, that some of those seizures were initiated by the Customs Service or by the State police. I think the evidence, on the information I have given to the House today, tends to justify and substantiate the Government's claim that we have done a great deal and are continuing to do a great deal in the fight against drug trafficking in this country. Speaker: Mr SCOTT
Title: ACCIDENT AT ADELAIDE AIRPORT
text: Is the Minister for Aviation aware of the crash last night of a Piper Comanche at Adelaide Airport? Can the Minister advise the extent of injuries to passengers and crew and to any members of the local community? Will the Minister seek a full inquiry into the crash?

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: ACCIDENT AT ADELAIDE AIRPORT
text: The facts, as indicated by the first part of the honourable gentleman's question, are correct. I am aware that a Piper Comanche aircraft on a private flight from Essendon to Strathalbyn in South Australia, upon being instructed to divert to Adelaide and subsequently reporting and experiencing a rough running engine and then, eventually, a cut-out, crashed in the environment of Adelaide Airport last night. I am advised that no major injuries were sustained by any of the occupants-they received minor injuries-and no injuries were sustained by any person on the ground. A full investigation of the accident-as in every case where there is an accident or an incident-is being undertaken by the Adelaide field office of the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation. I stress that this investigation was initiated immediately after the crash and was not instigated, as has been suggested in an Adelaide newspaper, in response to a request from any of the local politicians. When an aircraft crashes such an investigation automatically takes place. Questions were also asked in that paper as to why a disabled plane was brought in over a residential area. The aircraft was 4,000 feet above sea level when it crossed built up areas. I am advised that the pilot reported that he was able to maintain cruise and altitude. It was only when making preparations for landing that the pilot reported total engine failure. As I indicated earlier, there will be a complete investigation. We did not need to be urged to undertake that. Any suggestion that there has been some relationship between occasional phone calls from local politicians and that investigation is, of course, false. Title: CORPORATION
text: I thank the honourable member for her question. 1 think it is necessary to clarify the criticisms made before Estimates Committee A, particularly by Senator Rae. The ABC appeared before that Committee on 30 Mayas a result of dissatisfaction expressed by the Committee with certain aspects of the previous appearance by the ABC before the Committee. Speaker: Mr UREN
Title: LOCAL GOVERNMENT FINANCING
text: As honourable members are aware, the Whitlam Labor Government in 1973 for the first time made money available directly to local government. The grant was $59m. This year that amount has risen to $459m. Legislation was introduced in the Parliament in 1976 by the Fraser Government. That legislation is now under review'. There has been no investigation into the moneys directed from the Commonwealth Government to local government with no ties. Honourable members travel around the States. They are aware that every State in Australia has been critical of its State government, irrespective of politics. On the one hand, the Australian Government has been making money available to local government and, on the other hand, State governments have siphoned money away from local governments. Therefore, the Federal Government felt that it was time to examine all aspects of local government finances. The Government made the decision last August to proceed in this regard. During the period since then we have been having discussions with the States through the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and we have been having patient private discussions as well to try to get agreement on the terms of reference and also on the group to be involved. We have also had discussions with local government authorities and the States have now agreed to be involved. Regrettably, Queensland will not be a part of the inquiry although it has the support of local government in Queensland. The terms of reference and membership of the committee have been announced. The committee is to review the local government tax sharing arrangements and report on any changes required to improve the operation of the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act 1976 with reference to the respective roles of the Commonwealth and the States in regard to local goverhment; the purpose and functions of local government revenue sharing; the level and form of funding for local government available from Commonwealth, State and local government sources; and the principles which should determine the level and allocation of the local government revenue sharing funds between and within States. The chairman of the inquiry will be Professor Peter Self, Professor of Public Administration at the London School of Economics from 1963 to 1982. He is now a visiting fellow at the urban research unit of the Australian National University. Also on the inquiry will be Michael Eyers, an urban economist, Dr Judith Yates, a senior lecturer in economics at Sydney University, Mr Anthony Philbrick, Town Clerk and City Administrator of Brisbane City Council, Mr Noel Dawkins, Chief Executive Officer of the City of Canning in Western Australia-he is no relation  the Deputy Under Treasurer in South Australia, and Dr Ian Manning, a Research Fellow at the Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research at Melbourne University. I think honourable members will agree that that is a wide cross-section of capable lieve they will do a fine job of looking into local government finances which I hope will be in the interests of not only this Parliament but also the States and local government and that they will work together to solve our problems. We have dealt with the Committee stage, There has been over four hours of debate, This afternoon we are seeing an example of a classic tactic of the Opposition to try to waste the time of members on their side of the House who want to speak to this Bill by moving stupid censure motions, calling divisions and wasting the time of their shadow Minister who wanted to use the Parliament this afternoon to debate this Bill. If the Opposition will not use the time of this House to treat this Bill seriously, this is the sort of treatment it is going get.  bring a bit of rationality back into the discussion ,of this legislation, I say that the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) has never explained why the legislation is urgent. Quite large penalties are involved in this legislation and it is unlikely that we will have any opportunity to discuss these matters before this House agrees to the legislation this afternoon, if the Government uses its numbers to have it passed.
